metadata.case_name: Ajantha Transports (P) Ltd. & Ors. v. Regional Transport Authority & Ors. (Civil Appeals Nos. 1402/1974, 2254/1969, 1481-1483/1970)
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 1402 of 1974; Civil Appeal No. 2254 of 1969; Civil Appeals Nos. 1481 to 1483 of 1970

facts.text: Fourteen applications considered by Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore on 29th December 1971 for stage carriage permit on route Coimbatore to Sathyamangalam via Koilpalayam.

Five applications rejected for non-payment of prescribed fees; one withheld for want of Income-tax Clearance certificate; one disqualified under Section 62A of Motor Vehicles Act as amended by Tamil Nadu Act 16 of 1971 for having more than ten permits.
Palaniappa Gounder highest scorer with 9 marks, bypassed in favour of appellant Ajantha Transports P Ltd with 8.69 marks because Gounder granted permit on 8th October 1971.
P.V.K. Transports (second appellant) awarded 7.42 marks; appeals to State Transport Appellate Tribunal; only P.V.K. succeeded.
Break-up of marks under Rule 155A: P.V.K. - Residence 2, Workshop 2, Experience 2, 0.42 Sector Unit, Viable Unit 1 total 7.42; Ajantha - 2,2,1.63,0.06,3 total 8.69.

Tribunal rejected extra marks for P.V.K.'s branch office as not continuously functioning; preferred P.V.K. as single permit holder vs Ajantha's three; Ajantha recent grantee on 31st July 1971; P.V.K. permit on 8th December 1970.
Madras High Court rejected Ajantha's revision petition under Section 115 CPC.

Twenty-one applications before RTA South Arcot, Cuddalore for route Porto-Novo to Puliyangudi; five rejected as new entrants without experience; one from dissolved company; one applicant dead; six bad entries; five no/poor workshops; one inferior route knowledge; Chettiar preferred over Natarajan as better route knowledge and Natarajan recent grantee.
Tribunal preferred Kannon Motor Transport P Ltd as local enterprise; not disqualified by recent grant on another route.
Single Judge upheld; Division Bench set aside and remanded considering public interest in multiple permits at same meeting.
42 applications for route Chidambaram to Tirukoilur; after eliminations, RTA preferred Prabhu Transports on 23rd December 1965.
Tribunal preferred Kannon Motor Transports P Ltd (2 buses, workshop, experience from 1961, clean history, local, viable unit); recent grant on different route not sole disqualification.
Single Judge quashed Tribunal order for lack of comparative assessment and misunderstanding recent grants; remanded.
Division Bench dismissed writ appeals in limine, upheld remand considering multiple permits to same party on overlapping routes.

legal_issues.text: Is possession by a recent grant of another permit to an applicant for a stage carriage permit, either by itself, or, in conjunction with other facts and circumstances, a relevant consideration in either refusing or granting a permit to an applicant?
If it is, in any particular set of circumstances, a relevant consideration, what is the weight to be attached to it in the assessment of the comparative merits of rival claims?
Does the High Court's judgment or order in any of the cases dealt with by it call for interference by us in any respect in exercise of our powers under Article 136 of the Constitution?

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 47(1)(e) omitted by Madras amendment, so recent/previous grant not to be considered as disadvantage.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Tamil Nadu Amendment Acts 10 and 16 of 1971

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal held extraneous circumstances decisive: recent grantee and three permits vs single permit holder; applied mechanically without link to public interest.
Rules award marks for viable unit (more vehicles credit); Tribunal converted into demerit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 155A Tamil Nadu Motor Vehicles Rules

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in not interfering under S.115 CPC as Tribunal ignored rules and relevant considerations.

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 4 requires disposal per Section 47(1) despite marking; viable unit to be considered under public interest.
Tribunal considered relevant facts linking to public interest.

court_reasoning.text: Permit issuing power under Section 47 restricted to public interest; matters outside vitiate grant.
Recent grant or other permits neither qualification nor disqualification by itself; relevant only if linked by other facts to public interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nexus with public interest required; e.g., untested efficiency vs proven superiority.

court_reasoning.text: Weight depends on totality of facts; if equal, equality of opportunity (Art.14) may prefer non-recent grantee.
In CA 1402/74, Tribunal mechanically used recent grant/single vs multiple without nexus; ignored Rule 155A(3)(f); material irregularity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court should have interfered under S.115 CPC.

court_reasoning.text: In CA 2254/69, Division Bench remand proper; no final determination of rights.
In CAs 1481-83/70, High Court justified remand; multiple permits to one without merit appraisal unfair.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quasi-judicial power must be fair, impartial.

holdings.text: Relevance of previous grant only when other facts show nexus with public interest; by itself not affecting application.
Permit power under S.47 for public interest, including Art.14,19(1)(g).

precedents_cited.case_name: N.S. Ghouse Miah and Abdulla Shroff v. Regional Transport Authority, Cuddapah
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 47 not exhaustive; public interest broad.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pal Singh v. State Transport Authority Tribunal U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 47 not exhaustive; comply with STA directions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raman & Raman Ltd. v. State of Madras

precedents_cited.case_name: Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation v. Mangrulpir Jt. Motor Service P Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: RTA exercise per S.47 public interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Patiala Bus Sirhind Pvt. Ltd. v. State Transport Appellate Tribunal Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Consider experience, performance etc.; not equitable division.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raman & Raman Private Ltd. v. Sri Ramavilas Service Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No certificate if no final order.

statutes_cited.relevance: Criteria for stage carriage permits; public interest paramount.

statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for more than ten permits.

statutes_cited.relevance: Revision for jurisdictional error or irregularity.

outcome.summary: Civil Appeal No. 1402 of 1974 allowed; HC and Tribunal orders set aside; remanded to Tribunal for reconsideration per law laid down. Civil Appeals Nos. 2254/1969 and 1481-1483/1970 dismissed. Parties bear own costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand in CA 1402/74 for fresh consideration.

key_quotes.text: "The relevance of the previous possession or grant of a permit appear, only when other facts and circumstances, connecting it with and showing either the adverse or beneficial effects of its impact, in a particular case, on the interests of the public, are shown to exist."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on relevance of recent grant.

key_quotes.text: "permit issuing power under Section 47 is restricted to service of interests of the public generally in a broad enough sense to include due respect for guaranteed fundamental rights of citizens."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of S.47 to public interest incl. Arts.14,19.

key_quotes.text: "A fact which, in certain circumstances, is relevant for a decision on what the public interest demands may become irrelevant where it is not connected with such public interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court
